parts.text: Hello my name is Christina ladders and I'm going to have a conversation
with Alexandria economy. Four visible lives An
Oral History Project at the New York Public Library. It is February
eighth two thousand and fifteen and this is being recorded in my studio
in mountain town. Long Island New York
. Andrea tell me
about your earliest memories.
Well I grew up in Queens and I spent a lot of time with my grandparents
when it while my mom was working.
You know that was a very happy time for me. But there was
also always blood tests and doctors' appointments or
something medical going on you know for me. My
earliest memories are more of a stream of consciousness. It's very
hard for me to separate out single events. It's
become almost like a giant snowball
. I can no longer see the individual snowflakes interests or
who do you trust or believe in them at this time.
I didn't trust or believe in anybody.
I was more like a wild animal fighting for my life fighting to survive
while I was going through different medical situations.
Can you talk about your disability
. I had a kidney transplant when I was a baby
and many other complications through the years I've had
many surgeries on my legs. I use a wheelchair.
Have low vision learning disabilities.
What were you most afraid of when you were little. The so-called biggest monster under your
bed.
Well actually my monster didn't live under my bed. It was as big
as a hospital. Actually it was the hospital and the
entrance doors reminded me of a giant mouth.
You were the only disabled student in your school from kindergarten to third grade. What was that like.
Well actually it was for inclusion that
allowed me to be in a school for it will bite students actually
excluded me personally if
it was one hundred percent inaccessible you know it was an old building.
There were stairs everywhere. My mother and historians had to
carry me in my wheelchair and I you know I wasn't allowed to
move around the building because of safety reasons.
You know I remained in the classroom until the end of the day when they carried me out
. I didn't really learn anything. Mainly
you know I guess you could say I learned about what I was
isolation and loneliness in fourth grade you went to a different
school.
Can you talk about.
In fourth grade I went to a school where the
other students had physical disabilities or. Were medically
fragile and for the first time there was more of my kind
. You know I wasn't the only one. And actually
compared to some of the students I was more evil by you'd
. You know no longer
needing to be carried out during a fire drill. I was actually
able to push the wheelchairs of other students and that was very empowering
I know that horses are central in your life.
How did that come about. When I was about eight years old my family
found their pewter Quest back riding you know
we had to get doctors to sign papers and.
Just OK different things and have an Irish at the barn
for the first time I actually rode. I screamed and cried the whole time
and I think that was because it was the first time that I was
ever really out of my wheelchair moving and that was terrifying
but it actually it didn't last long.
You know knowing that every Sunday I would be with horses. It was
something to look forward to
because where since they didn't judge me or
ignore me they just accepted me. And soon
. Worsens and rioting became the center of my life and
everything else got in my way and it kept me away from the barn. What
was the prospect of graduation and going to college like
graduation in college or it was terrifying and surreal
. You know when you're when you go to a
school. That is one hundred percent accessible and
is able to accommodate your needs. The idea of
having to leave that safe place was just so scary you know I wasn't
sure how I was going to fit into college if I could do it you know I was still
recovering from major surgery. So it's just all very scary.
What were you like at this point. What did you just believe.
Well at this time my horseback riding actually
included competition.
And actually I hate it.
Taking a grand piano piano in my division at Hampton Classic
only a week before starting college. And you know on my first
day rolling into a classroom of thirty staring
students you know where I was the only. Wheelchair in the
room was a little I was a little
unsure. But then I was thinking to myself you know I'm the only grand champion
in the room that was cool it
was exciting. It was exciting because I actually
started to believe in myself and I was starting to connect
to definite spirituality.
When I was excited because I was able to see
the possibility you know I wasn't I was able
to start seeing myself as a whole you know not just
broken bits of this and that you're pursuing an
interesting career
. Can you talk about it.
Yes I am studying and analysis of therapy
working with dogs on Long Island. And horses in Tucson
My plan goal is to work with kids who have physical
disabilities that have a similar journey to my own
because I bring an interesting perspective to it and you know these
animals have always been drawn to me
and I feel they can help people with
disabilities come out of their dark hiding place.
Yes I know that you are a creative person. Tell me about that
Well Master Potter you know
I work in the old way meaning alternate firing. I
just love having my hands in the clay. I think that's because
Clay holds ancient knowledge and this is something that our ancestors
knew.
I'm a poet and I wote performance.
I make jewelry and amulets for musicians.
You've been through so much. What makes you keep going.
Well. I would have to say it's a possibility. And
Hope. You know that's the last thing but. People have to
hold onto it and. I would say that doctors should never
forget. That. You have to have hope.
And. You know as I got older
I figured out that disability doesn't define you. It's
just part of who you are.
It's it's part of me as a whole it's not separate from me
When challenge has conquered him I would have to say
fear because fear is my biggest
opponent in my existence.
I you know it's like flying against the wind or
endless falling into the black hole you know with nothing to grab
onto But you know every time that I am able to
pull myself back into the light it's just
another another victory for me. But you know
this warrior spirit here you know but. It's not the last battle
. There'll always be something coming up. Some sort of fear. What are you most proud
of. I would have to say. Getting out of my
wheelchair which is hard getting into my saddle which
is even harder. You know for an amazing people
that I work with I have to be really creative at times to help
me get into my saddle to ride and they've. Been
so creative at times. I have a whole team working with me you
know and working with a difficult horse and then all of a
sudden just everything falls into place it comes together so nicely
What message do you want a listener to keep
people are fascinated like Johnson's turn almost
anyone and the light will catch on
something beautiful. Or unexpected. Don't hate
us you know. Don't break our hearts for no reason. Don't pin
Yes just give us a chance. Thank you
Alexandria. Thank you.
